div.p:
9. V:Commodore Rogers called this morning at my house, and informed me that the experiment of cradling the frigate Potowmack, would be resumed this morning at eleven O’Clock, and invited me to attend— I went first to my Office, where D. P. Cook, member from Illinois, called and took leave— He was proceeding on his way homeward.— He told me that he had heard that during the latter part of the Session of Congress, Governor Edwards the Senator from Illinois, had ranged himself among the partizans of Mr Calhoun, for the succession to the Presidency. He said he had spoken to Mr Edwards about it, he had denied the fact; but Cook intimated that he nevertheless believed it to be true— But he said that as to the vote of the State, Mr Edwards well knew it would not be for Mr Calhoun; nor for any Southern man. Cook last Summer, married Edwards’s daughter. Until this Session of Congress, Edwards has constantly held himself out to me, as peculiarly and earnestly my friend— He has this Session sought no occasion of conversing with me, and I have no doubt has chained himself to the Car of Calhoun. As the time of that Election approaches it becomes daily more apparent, that the Election will be a contest between two factions in Congress, which is now an open market for the purchase of votes. The two Houses of Congress are the Pretorian Guards, who will in substance if not in form set up the Empire at Auction— It has been nearly so once before. Were it consistent with my principles to work for my own advancement any otherwise than by public service, it is now too late for me to commence bidding for the Presidency— Neither have I any faculty at driving such bargains— I told Cook that I thought it impossible the present Executive Administration should hold together through another Session of Congress— It is now nothing but a system of mining and countermining between Crawford and Calhoun; to blow up each other; and a continual underhanded working of both jointly against me, which has been the more effective, because I have neither creature nor champion in either house of Congress. At this game, Crawford is a much superior artist to Calhoun, whose hurried Ambition will probably ruin himself and secure the triumph of Crawford— Such is the present prospect— There was a Mr Evariste Mauri, who by dint of importunities and of recommendations, particularly from Mr Stokes, the Senator from North-Carolina, had obtained a nomination as Consul at Syracuse— The Senate rejected the nomination. He came this morning to solicit an appointment of agent somewhere—Some informal appointment to which the sanction of the Senate would not be necessary.— This I assured him could not be done.
I went with George to the Navy-yard, where the experiment of Commodore Rogers’s . . .tion was resumed. Met there, the President, Messrs. Crawford, Calhoun, Thompson, and some others. We remained there about two hours— The experiment proceeded successfully, but the movement of the vessel, as drawn up on an inclined plane out of the water was slow, and the cradling was not completed this day. Dr. Thornton came home with me, and I returned to my Office— Then called at the President’s where I met Mr Calhoun. A Mr Doolittle had been at the Office, as the Agent for the settlement of some old Accounts of Mr I. C. Barnet, Consul at Paris.

10. V: I called at the Comptroller Anderson’s Office, and told him that I wished now, with as much expedition as possible to proceed to the settlement of my Accounts— I left with him my own Statement of the account adjusted exactly to that which I had received from the Treasury, with the single exception of the half-outfit, upon the Mediation Mission in 1813. And I told him, I wished for a Certificate from him that this was the only unadjusted item of my Account; and that my current Salary as Secretary of State was now withheld on account of this question. At the Office there came Mr Richard B. Lee, who is always a Solicitor for Office; Mr Parrott, a Senator from New-Hampshire, and young Baldwin, son of the member of the house from Pennsylvania who came with an Account of the widow of the late A. Ellicott, which is unsettled— Mr Baldwin is detained here after the close of the Session of Congress by illness. There was a Quaker named Ennion Williams, who came about a dispute which he has with another quaker, named John Rowlett, upon interfering copyrights for certain Tables of interest— I referred him to Dr. Thornton— I now begin to take up Subjects, which from the pressure of business have been laid over till after the close of the Session of Congress; and this day answered a Letter, some weeks since received from Mr Deabbate, Consul General from Sardinia.

11. V:Mr Gales, Senior Editor of the National Intelligencer was this morning at my Office, with a first proof Sheet of the Congressional document containing the President’s two Messages to the House concerning Russell’s Letters; the Letters themselves, and my Remarks upon them. He came to consult me about the manner of printing them, but chiefly I believe to tell me, that he had lost his Notes, which he said had never happened to him but once before, of the debate or Conversation upon Russell’s Letter’s on Fuller’s Resolution to call for them— So that Gales cannot perform his promise of publishing that debate in extenso. The remarkable part of it was that Floyd, who had first moved for the residue of the Ghent Negotiation papers, and then specially for Russell’s Letter, and who but a few days since manifested great impatience to get the Letter, now opposed the call for it— Upon his first motion for the Ghent papers, he had pretended to want them, to ascertain whether there was any thing in them that bore upon his projected Settlement at the mouth of Columbia river— He did not make the same pretence in moving for Russell’s Letter, because it was evident from the short Letter of 25. Decr from Russell, communicated with the Ghent Documents, and upon the hint of which Floyd moved his second Call, that Russell’s Letter from Paris could have no possible bearing upon the Columbia river Settlement— But now, when Fuller moved that the call should be repeated, Mr Floyd objected to it, saying that he found from the President’s Message that the Letter had no relation, to his purposed Settlement at the Mouth of the Columbia river; and Mr Cocke, said the President had declined, sending it, on the ground of its leading to a misunderstanding between the Envoys. This change of tone and of tactics on the part of the movers of the mischief, is a signal incident in the course of these transactions, and I wished it might have been duly recorded by an authentic report of the debate— Mr Parish called from Mr Canning to ask for some papers, and Mr M’Glassin for his recommendatory papers— I spent the Evening at Mr Brown’s of Louisiana: the party was small. Mrs Adams being unwell, could not go. Chess with A. S. J. Baker—

12. V:15. Attended the Meeting at the Bath-room, and heard Mr Little preach from Philippians 1.27. “Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ.”— A sensible Sermon, not controversial. I passed the remainder of the day, with the exception of a walk after dinner, in my Library chiefly writing— In the National Gazette of Friday the 10th. is published Jonathan Russell’s Letter to Mr Monroe of 11. Feby 1815. with editorial remarks assenting of its doctrines, vouching for the authenticity of the copy published; extenuating and justifying Russell’s conduct in writing the Letter; but professing a willingness to hear what we have to say against it— The Letter itself is garbled— Not to the same extent as the duplicate, delivered by Russell at the Department of State, but sufficiently to let in the charge of a direct violation of instructions; and with it the extract from the Instructions of 15. April 1813 upon which he founds this pretended charge. It is apparent on the face of all these papers that they were furnished for publication by Mr Russell himself— And the peculiar profligacy of it is that he persists in this falsification of his own Letter, and repeats the charge of violated Instructions, after I had shewed him the Instructions of 19. October 1814— I wrote this Evening a Letter to R. Walsh, the Editor of the National Gazette; apprizing him that his copy of the Letter was not exact.

13. V:15.J. H. Eaton, the Senator from Tennessee came this morning to my Office, and requested to see the papers concerning the complaints against Genl. Purdy Marshal of West Tennessee; by two of his Assistants in taking the Census—Goodlet and Childress.— I shewed him all the papers, and told him what had passed upon the complaints transmitted to the President through Coll. Cannon— Purdy as Marshal wrote to me, requesting to be paid his account in paper equivalent to specie, alleging the express purpose of doing thereby justice to his assistants, and testifying that they had all faithfully done their duty. He was accordingly paid in paper equivalent to specie— But Goodlet and Childress complain that he paid them in depreciated Tennessee Bank paper, and retained to himself a part of the compensation allowed by Law to them. There are very strong testimonials from some of the most respectable people in Tennessee, in favour of Purdy, and Eaton, has a great regard for him— I told him that the President would have all possible deference for these recommendations and all possible delicacy and indulgence towards Purdy—but that in this affair he stood self-condemned, by his Letter to me demanding specie payment of his account— It was impossible to uphold him against these complaints; for if the President should disregard them, the sufferers would bring them before Congress by petition, and the whole transaction, would thus be disclosed— Eaton upon reading over the papers acknowledged that Purdy had been wrong, but requested that the President would take no decisive measure in the case, until after I should hear from him Eaton, upon his return to Tennessee, and that if finally the President should think it necessary to dismiss Purdy, he might be allowed the opportunity of resigning; both of which I promised— General Parker came and enquired, if there was any vacant employment under the direction of the Department of State, to which he could be appointed— There is no such vacancy— Parker was for some years Chief Clerk in the War Department, and afterwards Adjutant and Inspector General, with the rank of Brigadier General— At the reduction of the army last year the Office of Adjutant and Inspector General was abolished; but in the arrangements made under that Act, Towson, who had been Paymaster General, was made Colonel of the second regiment of Artillery, and Parker was appointed Paymaster General— This appointment of Towson’s, was the principal cause of the difference between the President and the Senate, and of their twice rejecting his nomination— The consequence of which has been, that Parker has been removed from the Office of Pay-master General, and Towson re-appointed to it— But from what the President said to me sometime since, he intended at all events to have dismissed Parker, from the Office of Paymaster-General; Mr Calhoun having considered himself as ill-treated by him— Parker told me this day, that Mr Calhoun, one day in February last, had him called into the War-Office, and taking the precaution
of having a Witness present, asked him if he had spoken in a Spirit of ridicule or censure upon his, the Secretary of War’s Reports— That Parker had said the question was of so extraordinary a kind, that he did not know how to answer it— Had any one said that he had so spoken?— Who was the accuser, and what had he charged him with having said?— Mr Calhoun had replied that he, Parker, knew whether he had so spoken, and could be at no loss to answer the question— That he had however declined answering a question, in such general terms, when he was neither told who had made the charge, nor what he was accused of having said— I suppose this was the decisive cause of Parkers removal— Young Baldwin came to the Office again, about the claim of Mr Ellicott’s Administrator— The Auditor, Pleasonton says it must be paid by General P. B. Porter, and charged in his Account as Commissioner under the 6th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— I wrote a despatch to R. Rush; to send by Mr Poletica, who is to embark on the 16th. for Liverpool.

14. V:15. Received a visit at the Office from Judge Cabell, of Virginia, and his family, with Mrs Wirt and her daughter— Mrs Cabell is a Sister of Mrs Wirt, and they visited the Department as a curiosity to be seen. J. J. Appleton, appointed Secretary of Legation to Madrid, came to ask for Instructions, and to say that he wished to visit his father at Cambridge, before proceeding to Spain. Mr Forsyth and his Secretary of Legation, T. L. L. Brent, do not agree together— Forsyth when he was here last year desired that another Secretary of Legation might be given him, and I have received two Letters from him since his return to Spain complaining of Brent— His charge against him is for inattention to business; but it appears Forsyth has de facto employed another person, O. Rich to copy his despatches and Brent’s non-attendance may be as much the effect, as the cause, of another man’s being permitted to perform his duties. This however was the reason, for the appointment of T. L. L. Brent as Secretary to the Legation to Lisbon, and Appleton to that in Spain. Edgar Patterson the manufacturer of paper came with some specimens of Letter paper; and Seaton, the junior Editor of the National Intelligencer—for an additional advance upon their printing the returns of manufactures, with the late Census, which I declined for the present. I called again at the Comptroller Anderson’s on the subject of the settlement of my old account. He wrote me a Note requesting me to send him his own Letter to me of 14. August 1819. After a search for it at my house at which I was not able to find it I went to his Office and told him I thought I had left it with him last week with my Account— He searched all the papers on his table without finding it and said he had been obliged to ask me for it, because no Office Copy of it had been kept. I returned again to my house; made a more effectual search among my papers; found his Letter and took it to him.

15. V:15. Called again this morning at the Comptroller Anderson’s to enquire if he had prepared the certificate necessary for me, to lay before the President, the question upon my Accounts— He had not; and said that the Auditor Pleasonton had made some difficulties, about separating this item from all others; though I had in my revised account given credit for every other disputed item. I asked him if it was Mr Pleasonton’s intention to raise any further question, contradictory to the Statements made and transmitted to me, by the Comptroller himself; and I added that Pleasonton’s conduct had been throughout the whole transaction unaccountable to me— I afterwards met Pleasonton between the Treasury building, and my own Office, and he asked me what sort of a certificate I desired. I told him, a statement that my account was adjusted with the exception of one item, the decision upon which would leave a balance due from me of so much, or to me of so much, specifying the sums; and that my current Salary as Secretary of State is now withheld from me on the allegation
that I am in arrears to the Government— At the Office, I had in succession Captain O’Brien, Mr J. J. Appleton, E. Wyer and the Count de Menou— O’Brien has obtained from Congress an act, explanatory of that which had passed two years ago in his favour, and came now with his whole budget of papers again asking me to settle his account— Appleton came for an advance upon his Salary as Secretary of Legation to Madrid; to enable him to proceed upon his journey and Voyage— Also concerning the Settlement of his Acct. for service in Brazil— Wyer’s object was to express his anxiety for the immediate publication of the Message with Russell’s Letters &c.—and to tell me what mischief Russell’s Letter was working as published in the National Gazette, against my reputation; and what an earnest expectation there was to see my reply— Menou came with a Note and a Counterprojet from the Baron Hyde de Neuville, who he said would have come with them himself, but that he was severely indisposed, and had been yesterday confined to his bed— The President likewise called at the Office, and I gave him the French Minister’s Counterprojet, for Consideration— I wrote this Evening to Mr T. Fuller, asking him for a minute of the debate on the passage of his Resolution calling for Russell’s Letter—

16. V:30.Appleton called first at my house and afterwards at the Office, about the settlement of his account, and at the Office about the advance upon his new Appointment— Mr George Hay, came to say that E. Wyer had applied to the President for an appointment as a secret agent to go among the Greeks— The President he said would refer him to me; and he supposed I was so well acquainted with Wyer, that he could give me no new information concerning him— I told Mr Hay, that I was well acquainted with Wyer— Mr Doolittle came again about the accounts of Mr I. C. Barnet— I obtained the President’s sanction for all the charges which were submitted before, and they were then said to be all. There are now others upon which it is not so easy to pass—they are however of small amount— John Rowlett came with a long Story, about his tables of interest, and his controvery with Ennion Williams. They have both been publishing libels upon each other in the Newspapers. Rowlett complains that Dr. Thornton has taken side against him upon an ex parte statement of Williams’s. I advised him to see Dr. Thornton himself, and told him that as they were both Friends, I should preach Peace to them both— Rowlett told me that although he approved entirely the doctrines of the Friends he was not in regular communion with their Society; but he said he would readily abide by any decision that I should make, in the dispute between him and Williams. I was obliged to come this day to the determination of dismissing John B. Colvin, from his situation, as one of the Clerks in the Office of the Department of State— He is when sober the most active, efficient and useful of all the Clerks, in the Department; but he is addicted to habits of intemperance, which have lately grown upon him to such a degree that since the beginning of this year, he has been more than half the time absent— I have given him repeated warnings, that I should dismiss him unless his attendance should be more regular—and his promises of an amendment have been equally frequent and ineffectual— Last week after a drunken bout of five or six days; following close upon a Letter of penitence and promise, asking the indulgence of one more trial, I told him that the first day he should be absent without leave, I should be compelled to dismiss him— He came some days after, and asked leave of absence for one day—on the plea that he was removing from one house to another. I gave him leave for that day— But he was then drunk; and has not been since at the Office— I desired Mr Brent this day to give him and his wife notice that he has been dismissed from the Office. I propose hereafter to employ him by the day, till he can find employment elsewhere— I received this day from the Comptroller Anderson, the Letter which he had promised me, respecting my old account. Took a solitary walk after dinner, and after returning wrote to my Son Charles— The weather grows so warm, that I find it very difficult to write in the Evening.

17. V:30. I called at Mr Anderson, the Comptroller’s Office, and he made a correction of a slight mistake in his Letter to me of yesterday. I went also to the Register’s Office, and asked for certified copies of several documents to be laid before the President, with the request for his decision upon the question in the settlement of my Account. At the Office, Captain O’Brien came again, about his unsettled claims, and brought his old budget of documents. But in addition to all this, he now made known a claim to me upon the British Government, for services at Algiers, which disgusted me very much. He pretends to have been for sometime, while in Office there as Consul of the United States, Charge d’Affaires for G. Britain; and now claims a remuneration of 1500 dollars; besides repayment of certain expenses. He shewed me a Letter he had written to Mr Bagot concerning it, which he said he did not send; but intimated the intention of making the application now to Mr Canning— Mr Parish brought me a note from Mr Canning, of enquiry if there was any Law or regulation, restricting the communications of the inhabitants of the Bahama Islands with Florida. John Rowlett, came again upon his affair with E. Williams. He shewed me a Letter from Williams to him, asking him if he would refer to arbitrators what damages he should pay him for having libelled him in the Newspapers; and his answer in which he says he is willing to refer it to my decision— I was at the President’s with drafts of Letters to M. Torres and to De Forrest, which he approved— Rain, great part of the day.

18. V:Gales and Seaton have sent me the proof sheets of the documents with the President’s Message to the House of 7. May— Russell’s Letters and my Remarks. They sent this Morning the last sheet, which I have myself revised— E. Wyer came again; very impatient for the publication, and telling me with some exultation, that the very day after its appearance I should be attacked in a piece of four Columns of which he knew, and which is already written— G. S. Bulfinch came to the Office, to tell me, that Mr M. Young one of the Clerks in the Department was dying, of dropsy in the Chest; and urgently soliciting the appointment in his place: he assigned various persuasive reasons for desiring the appointment, and referred to several strong recommendations which he had heretofore produced— Dr Thornton came and shewed me a Letter which he had written to John Rowlett, concerning his controversy with E. Williams, which contained a bitter sarcasm upon Congress, as consisting chiefly of Lawyers. After reading it, I asked him if he had sent the Letter— He answered, not yet. I then advised him before sending it, to strike out the reflection upon Congress, which with some reluctance he promised to do. Thornton is every Session of Congress, besieging them with importunities to increase his Salary. The good-will of every member is important to him; but he cannot resist the temptation, of passing a joke upon them; and that in an official paper, where if it had been ever so good it would have been misplaced. While we were at dinner, my wife’s brother Thomas Baker Johnson arrived— He has been some years residing at New-Orleans, where he is Postmaster. He is now absent upon leave, but that climate disagrees so much with his health, that his intention is not to return thither— He is now very ill, and much emaciated; much exhausted with fatigue also, having travelled, by the Stages in eight or nine days from Lexington, Kentucky to this place. Mr and Mrs Frye, with Robert Buchanan came and spent the Evening with us— Frye told me some curious facts concerning William Lee; and also that within a few days a bait had been held out from the Treasury to General Parker, but that it had not been big enough— The President who had been riding out on horseback with Mr George Hay, stopped at my door to tell me, that he had not seen till this day, a recommendation that I had sent him one of the last days of the Session of Congress of Coll. Malcolm, as Marshal for East Florida. He had therefore nominated another person; but he wished me to inform Coll. Malcolm immediately
that there was another place which he would give him, connected with the Indian Department. This notice from the President led me to conclude that Malcolm had found at the Treasury a more efficient friend than the Secretary of State.

19. V:15. Heard Mr Little, at the Bath-room; from Romans 9.4. “And Patience (worketh) Experience.” It was a cool and sensible discourse upon that class of delusions and impostures which are commonly called Religious Experiences. Judge Cranch of Alexandria was there, and afterwards called to see Mr T. B. Johnson, as did Mr Brown of Louisiana. Mr and Mrs Frye, and Robert Buchanan dined and spent the Evening with us. All the leisure of the day was employed at my Diary— I called at Coll. Malcolm’s lodgings to give him notice of the President’s intentions in his favour; but he was not at home— I left word requesting he would call at my Office at Noon to-morrow— I called also at Mr. Wilson’s, to return the visit of Captain Angus, who had left a card at my house the day before yesterday, but I found that he had left the City, yesterday morning.

20. V: Bathed this morning in the Potowmack, with Johnson Hellen and my Son George. At the Office I found Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy at my Office, enquiring if I had received information of Spanish Cruizers on the Coast of Porto-Rico, and Terra-Firma— I had received Letters to that effect, but Mr Brent, the Chief Clerk of the Department being absent, I could not find them, and told Mr Thompson I would send them to him when found— Coll. Malcolm came at the time appointed, and I told him of the President’s intention to employ him— He said he had already received the information from the Secretary of the Treasury, and that he was much gratified with the appointment— Captain O’Brien came again about his claims, upon which he said Mr Pleasonton the fifth Auditor thought it would be necessary that I should decide. He spoke to me again about his claim upon the British Government, as if he expected I should countenance him in it— I was at the President’s, and he directed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow at Noon, to consider the last Counterprojet from the French Minister— The President very unexpectedly asked me, what was the condition of the suit between L. Harris and W. D. Lewis— I told him it had not yet been tried. He said he remembered— I had last Summer written him a Letter, containing certain questions, relative to this affair, which he had verbally told me, he would answer at a suitable time— But that Harris having been here to apply for his testimony upon the trial, which he had then declined giving, he had thought it best to wait till the trial should be over before answering my queries— He asked if I could furnish him with a copy of them— I said I could— But that since that time, the Depositions of Mr Crawford; Mr Calhoun and myself had been taken in the case— That Mr Crawford had testified to certain things as having been said to him by the President, concerning me, which I had testified were not, and proved by recurrence to dates could not be true. Mr Crawford’s memory had failed him. The President said he did not see why he should not give his deposition in the case— I said that would be as he should think fit; but that at his own convenience I should wish explicit answers in writing to the questions I had addressed to him— He said he certainly would give them; and asked me if I had copies of the depositions— I said I had; and would bring them to him— He did not tell me why he spoke to me upon this subject now. Harris’s principal Counsel, Horace Binney has lately been here— After returning to the Office, I wrote to R. Walsh, and enclosed to him, one of the printed Messages, containing Russell’s Letters &c. which were this day made public— Mr T. B. Johnson was this day so ill that he was obliged to take to his bed— Finished this Evening, my Letter to the President concerning my Accounts.

21. V:30.Mr George Hay, called this morning at my house, and said he had heard I had dismissed J. B. Colvin from his Office as a Clerk in the Department, and he came to recommend a young man from Virginia named Linnaeus Smith, who was well qualified even to be the Chief Clerk of the Department— I told him that although I had dismissed Colvin as a regular Clerk, it was not my intention immediately to supply his place— I should employ him by the day, to give him time to look out for some other mode of occupation for his support. I added it was probable there would shortly be another vacancy among the Clerks of the Department, in which case I would readily consider the claims of Mr Smith, with those of others. But as there was a graduation of the Salaries of the Clerks I had made it a rule whenever a vacancy occurred of the higher Salaries, to advance those who had already served at lower rates, to them— He said he thought this very proper, and that Mr Smith would be content to enter the Department at the lowest rate of compensation in the hope of advancement hereafter. There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s, at Noon, attended by all the Members of the Administration, to consider new proposals of the French Minister— He has sent in answer to my Project of a Convention, not a counterproject; but a paper called substance of a temporary arrangement—as loosely drawn, as all his former papers. It is drawn in the form of Articles; but the Articles themselves are argumentative, and the side Notes are as spacious as the Articles— The first is that the Act of 15. May. 1820. and the French Ordinance of 26. July after, shall be repealed— The second that the duties collected under them shall be refunded— The object of these Articles is to give the United-States the appearance of retracing their steps— Mr Crawford was for agreeing to them— To which I warmly objected. The third Article, was a stipulation to restore deserting Seamen; to which I objected also, as belonging to a general commercial Negotiation— The other Articles made new difficulties about the ascertainment of the French and American Ton—renewed the proposal that the discriminating duties should be levied only upon the excess in value, of importations over the exportations in the same vessel; and proposed that the operation of the Convention should commence on the 25th. of August next. Mr. Crawford was for agreeing to every thing. When the Act of Congress of 15. May 1820 was on its passage through Congress, at the several Cabinet Meetings that were held on the subject, he never intimated an objection to any part of it: when the controversy with France grew into serious difficulty, and symptoms of dissatisfaction with this act began to appear abroad in the Country and in Congress, Mr Crawford declared that he had been against the Act of 15. May 1820. at the time of its passage— But Congress at their late Session shewed a determination so firm and so nearly unanimous to abide by that act, and the prospect is now so fair of obtaining at least a tolerable bargain with France, that Crawford is afraid of its being too favourable— He therefore is for granting every thing that the Baron will please to demand, because the more is granted to France, the less advantageous will be the Treaty to us; and the less advantageous to us; the less credit and the more discredit to the Secretary of State, who is to sign the Treaty— There was warm discussion between Crawford and me, upon several of those Articles proposed by the Baron; particularly the first and second, the repealing of the Acts, and refunding the duties levied.— As questions of interest they amount to nothing; but the appearance to the world would be that the United States retreated from their own ground. Crawford said it would be conciliatory— That we were suffering much by the present state of things—that in the last year there had been 38000 ton of foreign shipping employed in the commerce between us and France; which was more than there had been of French shipping in the commerce between us and France; which was more than there had been of French shipping employed in it, at any time— I agreed that it was very desirable we should form a Convention with France; and said that as to the main point in dispute we had already conceded more than I
thought we ought to have done— I believed also, that such would be the public opinion, should the convention be concluded— But certainly we should be taken to task for any unnecessary concession; Crawford said that if we negotiated in such a temper, no Convention can be formed— That if by admitting these Articles we retracted our Law, France also retracted hers— But I observed, the first retracting in this proposal would be ours— Mr Wirt, and the President observed that if we retracted France must go farther back, and retract her tariff of 1817. But Crawford said we had begun with discriminating duties in 1790. This is precisely de Neuville’s Argument, which has been a dozen times refuted in the Correspondence. So about the Article to restore deserting Seamen—Crawford said he was for agreeing to it; and said he was afraid de Neuville would insist upon it— The President and Calhoun were against agreeing to it, and I objected to it unless we could obtain some advantage for it in return— Crawford said there was a moral obligation to do it by Law, and Wirt said the State of Virginia had a law to that effect— I concurred in the opinion that on principles of Justice it ought to be the Law; but observed that Congress had four years ago refused to enact such a Law—and if it was to be conceded as a Treaty Stipulation to a particular Nation, it ought not to be gratuitously given— There was also much waste of discussion upon the Articles concerning the admeasurement of tons, and I remarked upon the arrant trifling in the Baron’s Project, upon a matter of detail so insignificant— Mr Crawford, Mr Calhoun and the President, all thought very favourably of the offer to levy the discriminating duties only, upon the excess of importations. Crawford said it would operate as an entire abandonment of all discriminating duties— I thought it was a snare to levy the duties upon Articles imported for re-exportation; and said that although the Baron had agreed to except the latter, I did not see how the details of the two principles could be reconciled together— I was afraid its first and immediate effect would be to raise questions on the meaning of the Articles; and that they would produce a new controversy instead of an adjustment— The Baron presents it however as an Article of his own suggestion, to be inserted subject to acceptance or refusal separately so that the rest of the Convention may be ratified either with or without it— The Baron likewise proposes that although the Convention shall be limited to two years, it may continue longer unless six Month’s notice be given by either party of its termination and that after the two years if no such notice should be given, the discriminating duties shall be reduced on both sides from year to year. Mr Crawford relied much upon this power of putting an end to the Convention in two years; but I thought its operation would be disadvantageous to us in either alternative; for if the Convention should operate in our favour France would give the notice and at the end of two years we should have to begin again. If it should operate against us, we shall be obliged to give the notice, and not only have to begin again; but incur the disgrace of having been overreached in the Negotiation— The Baron proposes that the Convention should be in force from and after the 25th. of August, to which I thought the first of September should be substituted. Mr Crawford supposed at first, that my objection was to the distance of the day, but I told him, it was to the day, and for the very reason, which had led the Baron to propose it because it was the festival of St. Louis, the kings fête, and the great holiday of the Bourbons. Crawford was for indulging him also in this humour— He said that de Neuville was now exceedingly anxious to return to France, and very desirous of embarking in a vessel, which is to sail from New-York, the first of next Month. He considered the proposals of the Baron as amounting in substance to a total abandonment of discriminating duties, which was the great object at which we had been aiming, and he thought we ought not to lose the opportunity of securing it. Mr Calhoun, inclined also to these opinions; particularly that the Convention would operate to abolish the discriminating duties, and that de Neuville was exceedingly anxious to go home with a Convention in his pocket, My great
objection was to the Articles stipulating the repeal of the Acts and the refunding of the duties which would exhibit us in a humiliating attitude to the world— Crawford said that in other respects the Convention would exhibit France in a humiliating attitude to the world; which I assured him would afford me neither consolation nor gratification. I had not the most distant desire of mortifying France, nor should I take one moment of pleasure in her humiliation— But between that and subscribing to the humiliation of my Country, there was an immeasurable distance which I never would traverse— As to the Article for the restitution of Seamen, there was one consideration, which might induce me to agree to it— There was a principle of Negotiation that each Article in a Treaty was to be considered as an equivalent for all the others; and all together as an equivalent for each— If the Convention should prove in substance to be an abandonment of all discriminating duties, and as such operate rather unfavourably to France; this Article might reconcile her to its continuance; as she considers it as very important, and as its operation would be all in her favour— For as the laws of France prohibit the shipping of foreign Seamen in French vessels, there is neither motive nor means of desertion to foreign Seamen in French Ports. The President finally desired me to make a draft of a reply to this project of the French Minister conformable to the impressions which had appeared to be prevalent at this Meeting. After I returned to the Office, Baron Stackelberg called and complained of a mistake in the translation of one of his Notes, published among the documents of the late Session of Congress— He shewed me the passage, which was really mistranslated. The documents were sent in, one of the last days of the Session, when I had no time to examine the papers, and in such cases, blunders are almost sure to happen. I made enquiry of Mr Ironside, who was the translator, who thought it was an error of the press. I told Baron Stackelberg that the safest way in future would be for him to send a translation with his Notes, as was practised by the French Minister; but he said he had not the means— Menou had however called this morning to correct a passage of his translation of the Baron de Neuville’s last Project— Mr H. Burhans, author of a Spelling book, came a second time to ask of me a certificate that it is the best of all spelling Books, which I again declined to give, though he now produced me a list of signatures of I believe two thirds of both houses of Congress. General Scott was here this Evening. Mr T. B. Johnson was very ill; confined to his bed.

22. V:15.Mr Miller Consul of the United States at Montevideo, called this morning at my house. He has taken a leave of absence for a few months to come home and visit his father. E. Wyer was at my Office; full of business, for the distribution of the documents— Russell’s Letter &c. Coll. C. S. Todd came; but the President has not yet determined what to do with him. I took to the President, my Letter to him, on the subject of my Account, with all the vouchers, and mentioned to him the question as it now stands. He asked me, if I had any objection to his referring it to the Attorney General for his opinion. I said certainly not.— I afterwards sent him a draft of observations, upon the Baron de Neuville’s last project for a Treaty— I took a solitary Evening walk.

23. V:15.Dr May and G. S. Bulfinch came this morning for a subscription for a Bell, for the Unitarian Church; for it is remarkable, that with a population of fourteen or fifteen thousand Souls, and at least eleven Churches, there is not a single Bell in the City. At my Office, Wyer came with an old manuscript Letter-Book, and book of characters, and read to me passages to shew me how he had always detested and despised Jonathan Russell, and Levett Harris— He valued himself much upon his book of Characters, from which he read me several extracts— Captain O’Brien came again about his Accounts— I told him he must make out a fair Statement of all his claims, and I would determine upon each item— I took to
the President’s a copy of my Letter to him ofJuly last, asking his answers to certain questions respecting the reference of the charges against L. Harris to Messrs.Crawford and Calhoun in 1818 and copies of the depositions of Mr. Crawford, Mr Calhoun, and myself, taken last November. I told him they were all taken upon the attempt made by Mr Harris, to discredit my testimony given in April 1821. I requested him to read with the utmost attention the interrogatories, and Mr Crawford’s, Mr Calhoun’s, and my answers to each of them—so as to possess himself entirely of the precise points of the question to be answered by him— As to the suggestion of his giving his deposition in Court, I must leave that entirely to his own determination— Whether a President of the United States ought in any case to give testimony in a Court of Justice was a question of great public interest, on which I would not wish to give an opinion, in a case so directly affecting myself. Mr. Jefferson had when President declined giving testimony; and I would ask nothing of him, which could be questionable with reference to his public duties— All I could say was, that so far as I could be personally affected by it, I was desirous that he should give his testimony, and should be glad if he would give it— But if he did not, I must earnestly renew the request that he would answer the questions in my Letter, and answer them in writing— I wanted his answers for my own satisfaction and for that of my children— He would suit the time of giving these answers to his own convenience and inclination— He promised to examine with the utmost attention the papers that I left with him; and to answer my questions, before he should retire from public life— I brought him also a Letter from General H. Dearborn, accepting the appointment of Minister to Portugal; at which he expressed himself much gratified— My remarks on Russell’s Letters were this day published in the National Intelligencer. After dinner I took a solitary walk, and called upon Mr J. H. Eaton, the Senator from Tennessee, at O’Neal’s— I found him convalescent from a bilious fever with which he was seized last Monday, the day upon which he had fixed for his departure— His physician thinks him not yet sufficiently recovered to proceed on his journey— I sat with him an hour or more in conversation chiefly upon Russell’s Letters. He told me he had never liked Russell much, but this character in which he had now placed himself of a spy upon the conduct of persons with whom he was associated in office, did not, at all accord with his ideas— As I was returning home I met William Lee, who stopped and began with me upon the same subject— He told me that in the years 1796 and 1797. Russell had been in France concerned in privateers fitted out at Brest; and so despised that the decent Americans in Paris would not associate with him.— Lee told me that his wife and family were gone off this morning to Boston.

24. VI:Dr Thornton came in this morning and began at once upon Russell’s Letters and my Remarks. He said he had a very poor opinion of Russell’s Letter when he first saw it, but this is not the impression which it has generally made— It has passed for being very well written— There is an air of plausibility about it, imposing at a first perusal— Its misrepresentations of facts are artful, its argument though radically sophistical, elaborate and subtle— There is a fatuitous affectation of diplomatic and legal knowledge, shallow and blundering in fact, but masking real ignorance under a shew of learning. The President really thought at first that it would make a profound impression upon the public mind— Walsh, the Editor of the National Gazette, a man of talents, and literature, was so much convinced by the argument, that without waiting for my answer he pronounced at once upon it, in favour of Russell’s position that the Treaty of 1783. was entirely abrogated by the War of 1812— All the Newspapers in which Russell’s Letter as published in Walsh’s Gazette has been noticed have spoken of it as an argument entirely conclusive, and Eaton last Evening in speaking of it, observed that Russell wrote remarkably well for so dull a man. G. Hay observed to me two days
ago, how surprizingly the real state of the question was misunderstood, throughout the Continent, adding that he had no apprehension, but that the public opinion upon it, would ultimately come out right— How that may be depends upon a higher power. I shall not satisfy prejudice, nor appease malice. There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— Mr Crawford absent, confined to his house by an intermitting fever; and Mr Wirt, at Alexandria— The question to be considered was upon a Report of Governor Preston, Commissioner to ascertain the losses of Citizens of Georgia by depredations of Creek Indians, for which by a late Treaty the United States have undertaken to make indemnity. They have gone back in search of such losses, to the year 1775— Tis chiefly for negroes and cattle stolen— Preston has made an award to the amount of more than 90000 dollars, and there are claims for interest reserved to perhaps double that amount— Preston has awarded in favour of claimants upon very feeble testimony; sometimes nothing but their own affidavit’s, and has allowed enormous prices for the value of Negroes and horses lost— He has invariably considered the proof of the loss, alone, as decisive in favour of the claim of indemnity for restitutions although restitution could only have been of the Negroes and cattle which were living at the time of the Stipulations in the respective Treaties— The claim of interest is the most important point, and I observed that it was made more so by its bearing on the claims of indemnity for Slaves, upon the British Government, in case the decision of the Emperor Alexander should be in our favour. Mr. Calhoun questioned whether the claimants ought not to have been held to prove the life of the Articles loss, at the time of the stipulation for restitution, as well as the loss; but that seems to require proof that could not be obtained— It was objected that the testimony as to the value of Articles lost had been received by one loser, in favour of another— On the whole the general impression was that Preston’s award should be taken as it was made; and as it had been so liberal to the claimants in regard to the Evidence, of loss and value, to reject the claim of interest as unusual, and dangerous for a precedent. But Mr Calhoun desired the decision might be deferred to another day when Mr Wirt, and especially Mr. Crawford might be present, and it was fixed for to-morrow, being Mr Crawford’s well day. There was some conversation upon three Resolutions of the House of Representatives, passed on the last day of the Session at the motion of F. Johnson of Kentucky. Two of them relating to the Office hours and Clerks in the Departments, and the third calling for a Report of a Navy-Peace Establishment— The first Resolution was that the practice of keeping Office hours only from 9 to 3 O’Clock, at the Departments, was not giving due attendance for the Salaries allowed, and ought to be abolished— There was some discussion whether it would be practicable or reasonable to require attendance earlier or later, or both— Whether attendance twice a day should be required, with an interval for dining; or a greater number of hours in one continued attendance. There are difficulties and inconveniences in both— I observed that the first Resolution had no application in fact to the Department of State, where the attendance the whole year round is from 9 in the morning till 5 or 6 in the Evening— Mr Calhoun said that his attendance was till 4. in the afternoon— The propriety of the Resolution itself was questioned, and the President thought it, an officious intermeddling on the part of one branch of the Legislature with the Executive Administration— I thought it was Legislation by one branch; and that if a different system of attendance was to be prescribed, it should be done by Law— But the main motive to the Resolution was the earnestness of F. Johnson to obtain a re-election— There is a Report to be made to the House on the second day of the next Session, by the Heads of Departments, and the Postmaster General; upon which Mr Calhoun observed that it should be made with a joint understanding. I think of introducing some new regulations with regard to attendance into the Department of State, for which
this Resolution, and another of similar character adopted on the motion of Mr Patterson of New-York, will afford the occasion— After dinner I took again a solitary walk. Called at Coll. Bomford’s and saw Mr Baldwin of Pennsylvania, who has been detained here by illness since the close of the Session of Congress— He is recovering, and hopes to be able to travel in a few days.— He began immediately to speak of Russell’s Letters and my Remarks, which were published in the National Intelligencer of yesterday. He said that which had struck him, as the most remarkable circumstance of the whole transaction was the falsification by Russell of his own Letter, and the shameless impudence of delivering at the Department of State, the pretended duplicate; as being the Letter he had written at Paris— He said that if he had done the same thing with a promissory note, it would have introduced him to the Penitentiary— And what was the difference between the two cases? a positive Law, inflicting the penalty— But the moral turpitude was the same in both— Count de Menou came in while I was at Bomford’s, he himself was absent—

25. V:30. Adjourned Cabinet Meeting upon the Georgia claims of indemnity for Creek Indians depredations— Mr Wirt was yet absent at Alexandria, and Mr Crawford, by indisposition, confined to his house. The President sent for him; but he sent word that he was unable to come out— These claims, which the U.S. in their last Treaty with the Creek Indians have undertaken to pay, are some of them as old as the year 1775—and nearly half of the amount admitted by the Commissioner is for losses before 1783. They are all for negroes, horses and cattle stolen by the Creeks, or absconded or strayed away from the owners into their Country— I examined more particularly the papers this day.— The allowance for the negroes was at an average of nearly 300 dollars a head— That for horses about 90. both considered as far above the current value of negroes and horses, at the time, and places when & where they were lost— On the advice of Mr Calhoun and Mr Thompson this day it was determined to allow all the claims admitted by the Commissioner, even those only recommended by him as fair, though not proved— But to decline allowing interest on the claims, for various reasons— One that interest is not usually allowed on claims against the public— Another that the allowance of the claims themselves is upon principles of great liberality to the claimants with regard to the evidence both of their losses and the amount of them— A third that the engagements of the Treaties were all, only for specific restitution of the Articles lost; and not for damages or interest upon their value. And the United States having undertaken only to do what the Indians had in the Treaties promised to do, are bound only to indemnify for the failure of specific restitution, and not for consequential damages, or interest— A fourth, that the engagement of the United States in their Treaty is to pay the amount of the indemnities found by the Commissioners to be due, in five annual Instalments without Interest; which shews that payment of interest upon the claims, was not contemplated by the parties; and if not after their amount and validity have been ascertained, a portion interest cannot be claimed for the prior time— I gave no opinion— But this subject will come before the Cabinet again— The President, asked us to call upon him to morrow immediately after Church; to speak with me of my draft of an Answer to the last proposals of the French Minister— At the Office, Coll. C. S. Todd came, but I was not yet prepared to give him his final Instructions— The President thinking it best to wait and hear from Mr Torres— Mr J. Rhea of Tennessee came to take leave— Going this afternoon— He spoke of Russell’s Letters, with much contempt; but what had struck him most, was his writing with such severe censure upon measures in which he had concurred. There are so many varieties of baseness in the whole of Russell’s conduct on this occasion, that men of any feeling of honour, have a choice of favourite points for special detestation— Calhoun spoke to me of it yesterday; and of a paragraph in the City Gazette, which charges him with having secretly worked to bring forth Russell’s Letter— He said he never
knew of the existence of Russell’s Letter till after Floyd’s call for the Ghent papers— I told him that Elliott the Editor of the City Gazette wanted to bluster himself into consequence. He said it was not Elliott, it was the hand behind the curtain, meaning Crawford, who did it all— Mr and Mrs Frye were at our house this Evening— I went with Mrs Adams, my Son George and Mary Hellen, to visit Mrs Decatur, at Kalorama— I had not seen her before since the death of her husband— For two full years she secluded herself entirely from the world; and great part of the time has been in a precarious state of health and of mind. She is now recovering, and within these two months has freely received company. She has with her two nieces of her husband—Misses M’Knight.

26. V:15. Heard Mr Little at the Bath-room; from Hebrews 11.25.26. “Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the People of God, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a Season;—Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt”— He gave notice that the new Unitarian Church would be dedicated this day fortnight— After Church I went to the President’s— He told me that he wished me to see the French Minister, Hyde de Neuville, and endeavour to arrange this Convention with him— That the difference between us, was now very slight— That de Neuville was very anxious to come to an agreement, wishing to leave this Country with friendly Sentiments and retaining a recollection of the kindness which he has experienced here— And he said it would give great satisfaction in this Country that an arrangement with France should be made, and would perhaps lead to a satisfactory arrangement of the trade with the British West Indies.— In going over the Articles however the President rather indicated the difficulties which he wished to be gotten over than the manner of getting over them. I told him that I would see the French Minister to-morrow, and endeavour to approach towards a conclusion with him.— I mentioned having received yesterday a Letter from General S. Smith stating that he saw by the newspapers, that our vessels were subjected to heavier duties in the Republic of Colombia than those of other Nations— He did not say what newspapers, and I knew not to what he referred— But I thought it would be proper to despatch Coll. Todd, as soon as possible, still in his character of an informal agent, and referring it, as originally intended to them whether an interchange of Ministers Plenipotentiary shall take place, or whether it shall be only of Chargés d’Affaires. The President agreed to despatch Todd immediately, but said he had no doubt of his right to send a Minister during the recess of the Senate: and he gave me to read a Letter from Mr Madison, which he had lately received, in which he gives his opinion in favour of the same principle. In the same Letter Mr Madison touches upon the state of Mr Monroe’s Cabinet, and the personal factions, which have been struggling against each other in Congress at their late Session. The President had alluded to it in the Letter to Mr Madison, to which this was an answer. Mr Madison speaks of it, as a grave and alarming symptom in our public affairs— The President said nothing of this part of Mr Madison’s Letter— Nor did I to him— Returning home from his house I met Mr de Menou, and desired him to say to the Baron de Neuville that I should be glad to see him to morrow at 2. O’Clock, at the Office of the Department of State— Menou called this Evening at my house, to say from the Baron, that he would attend at that time.

27. VI:30.Captain O’Brien came this morning to my house with the budget of his accounts upon which I am again to pass. He proposed to me to take the opinion of the Attorney General upon them— The Captain always mingles political conversation with the enforcement of his claims, and has many sources of indirect self-recommendation, as well as censure upon others. He talks upon every thing in a low and vulgar, but highly figurative language. He had no original education; was bred an Irish sailor, but says he was a Commodore of the Virginia fleet, under Governor Jefferson, during the Revolutionary War— He was master of the first American Vessel captured by the Algerines
in the year 1785—was nine years a Slave at Algiers; and afterwards several years our Consul there— He now resides at Carlisle in Pennsylvania, and has been a member of the Legislature of that State— He wishes me to think him yet a man of much political influence there; but he has in fact very little— He told me to day that my Remarks on Russell’s Letter were the best thing I had ever written— But he said he saw how it was— Mr Clay had picked up a stone; slily slipped it into Mr Russell’s hand; and whispered to him— There—do you throw this stone at that pane of glass, and break the window, and then I will get in, and you after me— From this O’Brien passed to Commodore Rogers’s inclined plane and ship-cradle; against which he had many objections— He talked also of the Quarrel between Captains Shaw and Hull—upon the Court-martial lately held upon Shaw and upon the proceedings concerning Barron— He says Captain Elliott of the Navy, who is now here, told him last Saturday that he had seen several hundred copies of a printed pamphlet containing Barron’s trial in 1807 for the affair of the Chesapeake, in the chamber of Mr Homans at the Navy Department, that Elliott asked O’Brien to procure for him a couple of copies of them, as he did not like to ask for them himself— O’Brien was in a rage about it, as an unconstitutional use of the public money by the Navy Department, to injure the character of Barron, because they would not employ him— Speaking of this, and of the personal factions raging in Congress, he said the Cask would soon burst its wooden hoops, unless it should be fortified by some iron ones— He told me that John Sergeant would be the candidate of the Hiesterites, for the next Governor of Pennsylvania; and George Bryan of the Findlayites— But as the old sow had more pigs than teats, Bryan was to come in upon a pledge to make a general sweep of all the Officers brought in by Hiester, and to restore all the old Findlayites. He said too that Coll. Gibson was now gone to see his brother in Pennsylvania, to make interest for Mr Calhoun; that Governor Findlay, and all his party here being thirteen of the Pennsylvania members of the House were embarked in that interest— That there was a schism about it in Pennsylvania, but they had agreed upon a truce till the next fall elections.— At the Office a Mr Lindsley came to solicit a Clerkship in the Department. The Baron Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister came according to appointment at 2. O’Clock, and we examined my project of a Convention and his Counterproject— There is little material difference between us, but he is tenacious upon trifles, and adheres so stiffly to his own loose phraseology that it is difficult to come to terms with him. As to the refunding of the duties levied under the Act of Congress of 15. May 1820 and the ordinance of 26. July of the same year, he said his principal motive for asking that was because it would serve as indemnity to the Eugene, the only one of the vessels which had been taken in the waters of Florida, and which had paid the duties— He insisted very earnestly on the Article for taking up and restoring deserting Seamen, and urged strongly the signature of a whole Consular Convention— On the question of fixing the amount of tonnage, by specified quantities of each Article he was not less stiff and unaccommodating, and as to the tonnage duties and light money he insists upon a discriminating duty on both sides of 5 francs— To the Articles that the Convention shall last two years; and longer unless six Months notice be given by either party of its cessation to the other; and that if continued beyond the two years the discriminating duties shall be diminished by one eighth from year to year; we agreed— Also to the proviso, that the discriminating duties should be levied, only upon the excess of importations over the value of exportations, with the exception of Articles imported for re-exportation— But as this is to be subject to distinct ratification by both Governments, I proposed it should be drawn up as a separate Article, to which he agreed. I finally gave him my observations upon his last projet, and desired him to send me a draft of a Convention in form, which we may discuss Article by Article, which he promised— Before leaving the Office however, he gave me a copy of the Correspondence between the British and French Governments
on the case of a French Slave-vessel having been taken, by a British Cruizer; for which Lord Castlereagh ordered the British Ambassador at Paris to make an apology, and offer of reparation, without waiting for a complaint— He said he did not mean to hold out this example of the British Government, as a rule for us to follow; but wished us to consider whether we could not give something like it, for the captures of the 5 french vessels by Lieutenant Stockton, and the case of the Apollon— He had shewn me this Correspondence some weeks since— I received a Letter from Jo: Hopkinson at Philadelphia— Evening walk with Mrs Adams and George. Mr T. B. Johnson is better.

28. V:30. The visitors at my Office were E. Wyer, Captain O’Brien, a Mr Herbert of Alexandria, who brought me a Letter of Introduction from judge Cranch, and who was an agent of J. H. March of the Island of Madeira, and Ennion Williams, who brought me models of two machines for surveying, of his invention. Wyer had as usual nothing to say—and O’Brien came about his Accounts which I had not yet examined— I wrote last week to the Spanish Minister, that Congress having declined making an appropriation to run the boundary line with Spain according to an Article in the Treaty of 22. February 1819. it could not now be run— On looking over this day the general Appropriation Act of the last Session, for another purpose I found that the appropriation had actually been made after several contradictory votes upon the subject between the two houses— I went to the President’s and informed him of the mistake I had made, and observed that it would now be necessary to proceed upon the execution of the Article, to which he assented— He authorised me also to purchase for the public the late Captain Ingraham’s journals of his voyage to the North-west Coast; a proposal for which has been made, by Ingraham’s widow and Son, through William Tudor— I wrote to Tudor, accordingly— Answered also a Letter of C. A. Rodney— Evening walk with Mrs. Adams and George. I called also this morning at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office; concerning the settlement of accounts of Mr Maury, the accounting Clerk of the Department of State— Since the late Session of Congress there is a more scrutinizing and captious spirit among the accounting Officers of the Treasury than before, and they cavil at trifles. The Comptroller had, as Maury said objected to an account for Books which I had purchased of Wells and Lilly at Boston, thinking some of the prices very high— Anderson disclaimed this altogether— He had also told Maury that my approbation must be certified to every receipt and account that he presented— I observed to Anderson that this would give me much additional, and useless trouble, and the same object would be answered by my certifying Maury’s general account from quarter to quarter—to which he agreed— He spoke much to me also of Russell’s Letter and my remarks upon it, which he thought acrimonious— But he said he thought very indifferently of Russell’s character and even of his talents— He also told me, that Russell’s hostility to me, was of long standing, and had long been well known to him; particularly in the winter of 1816 and 1817.

29. V:15.Mr de Menou came this morning from the Baron Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister, with a project of a Convention drawn up in form, with a Translation— He told me he was going this day to Baltimore, to return to-morrow. Mr R. J. Meigs, the Postmaster-general, called to visit Mr Johnson, who is within these two days a little better— At the Office Ennion Williams came to ask an order for the restoration to him of his models, which he had left at the patent Office merely to be exhibited, but which by a rule of the Office, are now detained there— I told him I thought he could obtain them by application to Dr Thornton. A Mr Armstead of Norfolk, brought me a Letter from Mr T. Newton, the Representative from that district, and as I understood from him, his brother in Law— He has an old claim against the Danish Government, for the loan of money, the proceeds of a Cargo which Captain
Barron carried there for him and sold— The loan was for six Months, but when the time of payment came, it was tendered in depreciated paper, which Barron declined taking, and could not have taken without heavy loss— I told Mr Armistead that we had neither Minister, nor diplomatic agent at Copenhagen; but there was a Consul; and if he thought proper to pursue his claim before the Danish Government, I would instruct the Consul to give him every assistance in his power. He said this was all he expected— That he had expected to have met Captain Barron here— But he would collect the papers and send them on by Mr Newton when he should come on to Congress at the next Session— Mr Bestor came with a budget of recommendations, and a solicitation for employment as a Clerk in the Department— Mr Canning came and said he was informed by Mr Barclay the British Commissioner under the sixth and seventh Articles of the Treaty of Ghent, that General P. B. Porter, the American Commissioner had requested a postponement of the meeting at Utica upon which they had agreed for the 3d. of next Month, until the 17th. He said that from Barclay’s Letter, it seemed to be too late to object to this postponement, as he seemed already to have acceeded to it. But that he, Canning, could not approve it, and it placed him rather in an awkward situation— I told him that I had received no intimation from General Porter, that he had asked, or intended to ask for this postponement; and therefore knew not what had been his motive— But I would immediately write to him, and would mention the objections to any delay in proceeding to the execution of the 7th. Article of the Treaty; which I did— I wrote also to the Spanish Minister Anduaga informing him of the mistake I had made, in supposing that Congress had declined making an appropriation for running the line under the Florida Treaty— Walk after dinner with Mrs Adams and George— We met E. Wyer who came home, and spent the Evening with us.

30. V:30. Bath in the Potowmack, at the Mouth of the Tyber, with Johnson Hellen and George. G. S Bulfinch was here, to renew his solicitation for a Clerkship in the Department. At the Office, Mr Ironside introduced to me, his son, who is a young lawyer in New-York, now a visitor to his father. Captain Tingey came to visit me, on his return from Boston, where he has been, presiding in a Court martial, upon Captain John Shaw, and Lieutenant Abbot of the Navy. He says the sentence of the Court has not satisfied any of the parties. Coll. Todd called again at the Office; but I had not yet received an answer from Mr Torres, to the Letter which I wrote him last week— I took to the President the project of a Convention, sent me yesterday by the French Minister; and told him that there was no material point left, upon which we could object to concluding it— But I said it was a Convention which would not satisfy the people of this Country; and it was my deliberate opinion that it would have been a wiser and more successful policy to have adhered inflexibly to the principle of entire reciprocity, and to have admitted no discriminating duties on either side. He said that was his own opinion— But that the Nation was uneasy under the interruption of our direct intercourse with France; and until the late Session of Congress we could not calculate upon the firmness, and especially upon the unanimity, with which the ground taken by this Government would be supported. I said that would be precisely the mainground of complaint against the Convention; for the Executive will be charged with agreeing to this heavy discrimination, after knowing that Congress approved of the opposite course— However we were already so far committed, in the points to which we had acceded, that I saw no justifiable reason for breaking off the Negotiation— The stipulations that after two years if the Convention continues the discriminating duties shall be diminished by one eigth from year to year, and that they shall be levied only on the excess of importations over the value of exportations may perhaps partly reconcile our people to the Convention, but at all
Events it was now too late for us to retreat. I left the Translation of the Projet with the President for his Consideration— Mr Calhoun came in while I was there— He said Coll. M’Rae, who was at Wheeling wished to be informed whether he should be employed as Commissioner to run the line, under the Florida Treaty— I mentioned the Letter I had yesterday written to the Spanish Minister to rectify the mistake I had made, under the belief that no appropriation had been made for the expense of running that line. We are to wait for Mr Anduaga’s answer, before replying to Coll. M’Rae. Mr Calhoun consulted the President also upon what was now to be done concerning the Dauphin Island fortifications. Congress have refused appropriations for continuing them; and large advances have been made to the contractors, which must now be recovered back from them;— Calhoun’s project seemed to be, to bring suits at Law upon the Bonds and Mortgages of the Contractors, who might plead the breach of contract on the part of the Government, by the withholding of appropriations, and recover judgment against the Government— The President asked my opinion, and I said that according to my first impressions, the proper course was to bring an action for monies had and received against the Contractors for the advances, and if the contract had been broken on the part of the United States, by the refusal to appropriate, the only remedy that I knew for the Contractors was by petition to Congress— Calhoun afterwards observed that the Contractors themselves had failed to complete their work within the time; though the Government had not intended to take any advantage of that— It changed however the aspect of the question. The President concluded to take the opinion upon it, of the Attorney General. Calhoun’s object is to escape the investigation of the Contract by Congress— Evening walk with Mrs Adams— We met Genl. Van Ness who dismounted his horse, and walked with us.

31. V:30. Bath with Johnson Hellen and George. At the Office there came a Mr Sherburne, a Lieutenant in the Navy, who asked to have a long Conversation with me, upon the survey of our Coast— The measurement of an Arch of the Meridian, and Mr Lambert’s calculation of the Longitude of this City; with which he finds great fault. I appointed ten O’Clock to morrow Morning to see him at my house— Mr Bestor came again to renew his solicitation for employment—pleading poverty, distress, and a sick family— I was at the President’s and received from him, minutes for a Note to the French Minister upon Stockton’s captures of French Slave-Vessels, and for the projected Convention— Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy was at the President’s consulting with him on the measures to be taken for the suppression of the Pirates in the West Indies. The President said something of a Cabinet Meeting to morrow or on Monday— I rode this Evening with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen to Mr Frye’s, and he walked home with me.

Day. The distribution of my time between my house and my Office, is much the same at all Seasons of the year; but my occupations are modified by the changes of Seasons, by the Session and the Recess of Congress, and by the succession of the current business of the Department— Since the adjournment of Congress and through this Month I have risen between 5 and 6— Journalize till 9. and after Breakfast, till Noon. Attend at the Office, till 6. with a call of an hour three or four times a week at the President’s—dine between 6 and 7. Walk an hour or two, and write an hour or more in the Evening till ten or eleven. The two last Morning’s I have bathed in the river, and the Summer is already setting in with so much fervour, that I must henceforth give up Evening writing for three or four Months— I find the effects of the Summer heat more oppressive upon me than they ever were before— The intensity of the pressure upon my mind increasing, and the drowsiness of relaxation from it, increasing at once, and about in the same proportion.
